title: Eurydice Dixon's killer Jaymes Todd says life sentence is too HARSH as he never committed a crime
text:
Eurydice Dixon's twisted killer has claimed his life sentence is too severe because he never committed a crime before he raped and murdered the comedian.

Jaymes Todd, 20, is fighting for a lesser sentence in the Court of Appeal after killing Ms Dixon in Melbourne in June 28.

Todd was jailed for life and must spend 35 years behind bars before he can apply for parole.

In a court filing, Todd has now claimed his life sentence was 'manifestly excessive', with his lawyers arguing he is of 'otherwise good character'.

Jaymes Todd, 20, is fighting for a lesser sentence in the Court of Appeal after his brutal June 2018 crimes

Todd stalked 22-year-old Ms Dixon (pictured) for more than an hour as she walked through Princes Park after a comedy gig on June 12 last year

Todd's lawyers are fighting for his punishment to be reduced given his youth, background, early guilty pleas, remorse and his Asperger's syndrome.

'He was a young offender who had no prior convictions. His upbringing had been characterised by dysfunction, chaos, filth, squalor, isolation and neglect,' read their application, obtained by the Herald Sun.

'Those considerations in combination rendered a sentence of life imprisonment particularly severe, more severe than that disposition would already be but for their presence.'

They said it was 'unreasonable' for Justice Stephen Kaye to sentence Todd to life with no chance of parole until after serving 35 years behind bars.

Justice Kaye ignored submissions by prosecutors against a life term. Todd's defence team said while the judge wasn't obligated to, 'he ought to have'.

'A sentence other than life imprisonment was open — and by virtue of the principle of parsimony, thus required — to be imposed,' they argued.

Todd stalked 22-year-old Ms Dixon for more than an hour as she walked through Princes Park after a comedy gig on June 12 last year.

After the murder, the then-19-year-old bought a pie and coffee, went back to the Carlton North crime scene and googled rape and pornography as well as stories about his victim.

He was diagnosed with sexual sadism disorder while in custody.

Before the murder, Todd fantasised about violent non-consensual sex culminating in a woman's death.

During the sentencing, Justice Stephen Kaye said Todd's 'dark and sick fantasy' and the disorder drove the crime and not his mild autism.

Todd pleaded guilty to rape, murder, attempted rape and sexual assault.
